I made a reservation; received a confirmation; bought the air tickets and then they said they could not give me the room.All the process was extremely disappointing; first time I get treated like that; really no respect also in the management of the problem.Wanted to make sure you all know. Be aware; if that is the approach I doubt the rest can be worth.

It is kind of confusing that there is one name but three accommodation facilities.We stayed at \Anis Cottage\" with Kurien and Anis and we highly recommend it to everyone! When we arrived (it is quite hard to find; make sure you get the phone number of Kurien when you call the tourist desk in Kochi) the other guests greeted us with the words \"welcome to paradise\"! For 2500 Rs. we had the best Indian food ever (and so much!!); a beautiful beach nearby (at night we could hear the ocean; it is very close) and lovely people around us who cared for us and made sure we did not miss the Theyyam ritual. Don't miss this; it is such a wonderful place! :)"

I have been staying in Costa Malabari Guest house in Kannur for many years. First time one week; year after 2 weeks; then a month; and I will carry on and on.I just want to say thanks to Anni and Kurin the owner of the house. So wonderful; so kind and helpful. Anni is so popular for her cooking; but she is shine and when you tell her she is the best cook in the world she smiles at you. Her marvellous and great smile!Kurin her husband gives you all the information you need; at any time he is there to help you. His suggestion about the Theyam; the ritual dance;is perfect. He knows where you have to go; he knows all details about your journey; he changes money; he calls you a tazi or tuk tuk he is just perfect.Kurin and Anni two great friends; they will be always so special; and arriving in Costa Malabari is just HOME!!!In Costa Malabari you meet all kind of interesting people; every lunch dinner breakfast was a joy; all together to share experiences; and Annie is there near you; giving food; delicious food and love.I can carry on for ever but once more justTHANK YOU

Perched on a cliff-top above a small cove; this guest house is the stuff of dream getaway holidays. It is certainly not a luxurious experience. Rooms are large if basic; cooled by a sea-breeze and fans. Showers are best taken by the bucket method; and the power supply is occasionally spotty.Access to the beach is via a ladder-like stairway. The cove itself is quite small and the beach is sometimes inaccessible because of the high tide.Kurien's hospitality is legendary; and rightly so. He is a charming and helpful host who will help guests experience the fascinating Theyyam rituals held at small family temples at any hour of the night or early morning. The food here is plentiful and the cooking extraordinarily good. Veg and non-veg options are available.This stay will be a distinct highlight of our India trip.

We spent 3 nights with Kurien and his family and staff. Kurien certainly is a cheerful man with excellent English who will make sure you can experience the amazing theyyam rituale. The beach there is close; empty and calm; and the small adjunct village friendly. Rooms are clean and basic and you can use the internet free of charge (there is a computer). We had a great time there. We wished the food would have been spicier but I guess its our fault for not saying anything. Even though we had a relaxing and happy time there; we did find our stay fairly costly.

I had read about Costa Malabari in a guidebook but warmly recommend it for anybody looking for a homely stay away from the hassle of moving around South India. I loved the simple house of Costa Malabari 1; 5 minutes away from the beach is a nice walk; the area has nice pathways amid prim houses and lush vegetation; and just reading on the terrace or enjoying the communal food every lunch and dinner absolutely fulfilled my expectations.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Rooms are not the selling point - they do the job; the whole house is very simple but has all you ne...

Review_Content: We stayed at Costa Malabari 2; you have a secluded bay right on your door step and at night you fall asleep to the sound of the waves lapping at the shore. Most of the time the beach is deserted and the perfect place to peacefully enjoy some sun and sea. The Keralan food here is delicious! We especially enjoyed the lassis with lunch and the fresh fish served with dinner; there was a real variety of dishes and fresh fruit juice served with omelets on great brown bread for breakfast! The rooms are spotless with unique indian furnishings. You have a shady terrace to sit out on. The owner is great at organizing trips to Theyyam and we used the same Auto driver to go and see the weaving co-operative; beedie factory and fort. We really enjoyed our stay here; thanks so much

Review_Title: “Must experience a Theyyam ritual while you are here”
Review_Content: We stayed two nights in Costa Malabari 2 (there are three). Our first floor room had a window facing the ocean which is very close so we could hear it when lying in bed. Huge simple room with great food. The building is on a small cove with a few other buildings. You get to the cove down some steps and we had it to ourselves most of the time for swimming and hanging out. You can walk round to longer beaches if you want. Kurian the manager organised a trip to a Theyyam ritual for us. It was to bless someone's house and was a fantastically powerful experience. This place is very hard to find; no signage - so you need to Kurian to guide you from the temple on his motorbike or get them to arrange a pick up. They ask for payment in advance by cash transfer which incurred a charge for us increasing the price by 50%.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: There are two rooms on the ground floor with a shared verandah; both face out onto the garden/ocean...

Review_Content: We stayed 3 nights at No 2 house perched on the cliff top overlooking an idyllic palm fringed beach. We chose to stay here because we wanted to attend a Theyyam ritual - and this was arranged by Kurian; who is knowlegeable and passionate and keen to provide an authentic experience for visitors (written about in William Dalrymple’s book; ’Nine Lives’). He’s also passionate about cooking; and provides delicious well thought-out meals which; we suggested; his visitors might like the recipes for. We were abe to use our laptop by taking a short magical walk through the forest to sit on the verandha of another of the three houses.

We stayed for a couple of nights (and I wish it had been more) at Costa Malabari; which is at a place called Thottada; a 20 minute auto ride from Kannur itself. It's a 5 minute walk from some beautiful; tropical beaches; and for two days we mostly had them pretty much to ourselves. The sea's warm and great for swimming in - we spent hours floating around and swimming up and down - and the golden beach is lined with palm trees; with red kites circling overhead.Costa Malabari itself is a smart; comfortable guest house; in a converted mill building; run by a friendly man with very good English. It's relatively basic but it was very peaceful; the bathroom was clean and spacious; and the food is really very good. They have a good selection of books and travel guides to read; and a nice veranda outside where you can while away an evening on the deck chairs; looking out onto trees. The manager will organise a trip to a nearby Theyyam ceremony in the evening if you want to go; as well as any transport to and from Kannur.The guest house wasn't the only building on the beach; as I'd imagined; but it's in a quiet little place with no shops or beach shacks at all - just some private houses and homestays scattered around behind the sands; and little sandy paths through the palm groves. If only there had been a hammock or two to lie in; and maybe a bottle of beer in the evenings; it would have been perfect. I'd definitely go back again.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: We stayed at Costa 2; which is a few minutes further from the beach and I think it had five rooms. O...

Review_Content: This place was a pleasant surprise. First; the food is absolutely AMAZING. The small beach down the steep cliff is lovely; the jungle setting is beautiful; and the staff are very friendly and helpful. Make sure you know which building you're staying in; as there are 3. I believe #2 is the one on the cliff over the beach. One of the others is about a 5-10 minute walk through the jungle -- the only place where internet was actually working when I was there. The rooms are very basic; clean with fans and screens; but you probably won't want to spend much time inside. Rickshaw fare from the train station should be Rs 150 -- use prepaid or be prepared to bargain; since they will charge you twice as much. Also be sure they know which house to go to; especially if you haven't been there yet -- it can be hard to find any of the staff at certain times of day; and they tend to move around.

This was one of the highlights of our trip to South India - it was so relaxing. We had booked for 4 days but in the end stayed for 6! We stayed at the original Malabari house ( the converted weaving shed rather than the cliff top house) and would recommend it. The rooms are simple; clean and comfortable but the food is lovely and varied and there is plenty of it. We particularly enjoyed the lassi; salads and desserts. Kurien is a great host and made us very welcome.We enjoyed bird watching both from the terrace; near the shore and by the wetlands. On 4 out of the 6 days we also saw dolphins swimming in the sea. Twice we saw a mongoose on the path near the wetlands.I loved Costa Malabari and I would hope to stay there again one day.

My wife and I stayed in the house on the cliff in April 2012 for a week.It's a quiet place above a small beach (which is awash at high tide) accessible via a steep iron staircase from the hotel garden.The main or bigger beach is a ten minute walk but expect to get 'ogled' by youths from the village.The best room from our point of view was on the first floor; a large baisc room with a 'bucket' shower and windows on 3 sides and 3 ceiling fans - no AC.The minus is there were civet cats in the room space running around and fighting at night! Not a thing you get used to....On the plus side were were taken to a local Theyyam (Hindu religious Festival) to see the spirits being ejected from a village by Kali and Shiva. The owner of the house is knowledgeable on Theyyams and always had time to talk to us.Kannur is a few Kms away by tuk tuk or taxi on rough roads and really isn't worth a visit so if you stay here you are isolated without transport. We were happy with that situation as we just wanted peace and quiet!The house is being renovated this year with 'decks or balconies' for the groundfloor rooms and the civets hopefully will be banished from the roof space!Food was good and plentiful; 3 meals a day must be included as there's nowhere else in the vicinity to get any.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: There are 3 bungalows belonging to the same owner in the vicinity; we chose the one on the cliff and...

Review_Content: This is in a lovely spot above a small and beautiful beach. The veggie food was first class and plentiful; served with fresh fruit juice or lassi. There are quiet and peaceful walks nearby and help was given for us to go to the local theyam. A great opportunity for time away from hustle and bustle.

Review_Title: “Great location; great food; friendly helpful staff”
Review_Content: A lovely secluded beach in a quiet; undeveloped area (shame about the ugly construction going on next door which we were told is against all building regulations for the area). The staff were very friendly and helpful - Kurien is a great source of information on Kerala; Kannur; and the local Theyam rituals. The food was fantastic - simple and tasty. A lovely place for a relaxing few days.

We were lucky in that a room was available in Costa 2 for the 3 nites which is right on the seashore. There are 3 houses each with about 5 rooms and beautifully managed by the \gracious host\" Kurien - the food is simple veggie Keralan; not the haute cuisine as suggested in some guidebooks; Kingfisher is available. we would not have enjoyed this idyllic spot if we had been accommodated in one of the other locations - so book well ahead."
Room_Tips: Room Tip: For most pleasure get Costa2; perhaps stay in 1 or 3 for the first nite.

Review_Content: My husband and I stayed here for three nights; and it was great. We stayed at Costa 2; which is situated on a cliff right by the beach (access to beach by a set of stairs). This is definitely the property you want; as the others are a few km from the beach. The beach is small; private; nice sand; and warm water. The rooms are VERY basic-- nothing more than a bed; fan; and a wooden desk. The food was tasty; but simple; and we also had lots of fresh juices. Other reviewers complain that the owner is never around; but to me this was a nice plus-- I felt that we were being left alone to just relax and enjoy the sun and the beach; and that is what we did. The owner came by every evening around dinner time and was very helpful in answering our questions; and arranged for us to see Theyyam; which is pretty neat. We also visited the local handloom cooperative; which was very interesting. The property is not beautiful; and I agree with other reviewers that some minor sprucing up would go a long way. There are only a few rooms in Costa 2; and the other travelers we met were really lovely people.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Make sure you request Costa 2 if you want to be on the beach.

Review_Content: We stayed here for two nights and we came to Kannur to see the ritual of Theyam. We knew it might be difficult to organise; but the owner organised everything and it was very smooth - the ceremony was wonderful. He also helped us arrange rickshaws and even an early breakfast when we had to leave early. The meals were great and very good value - lots of fresh fruit; lassis and as many cups of chai as you can drink. The other travellers were great fun. The beach is nice; and we visited the handloom factory in town - an interesting experience. Definitely recommend.

We stayed in the cliff house (Costa Malabari II) for a couple of nights. When we first arrived; we had the beach literally to ourselves. Great location; watching the sunset from a dekchair on the cliff; listening to the sounds of the waves. A big thank you to the wonderful cook; the food is absolutely fantastic! It´s also a treat for the eyes since all the colours come out nicely as food is served on bananaleaves.The host; Mr. Kurien; is very knowledgeable on Theyyem dance rituals; and he arranged for us to attend a dance in the hinterland of Kannur. Spectacular ! If you wish to know more about this ancient ritual; read \ Nine lives\" by William Dalrymple; he has a chapter on a dancer from Kannur. Would love to return and attend more Theyyem rituals. May be next winter; who knows.Thank you for your hospitality !"
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Top room in the house on the cliff

Review_Content: in fact i am still here!advised by a friend to stay here; only wish it could have been longer.rooms are great; mosquito nets; great bathroom. annie; the cook magnificent! her food is simple; delicious and i'd like it every day.the beach is great. easy to get around.debbie australia
Room_Tips: Room Tip: decide how long you wish to stay; as like i did booked for 2 nights; and wanted more.

Review_Content: Kannur beach is a jump off point for the Hindu Theyyam festivals; which are a must see. Kurien; the manager is an intelligent; knowledgable; and gracious host. He can be extremely helpful arranging trips to the Theyyam ceremonies and for ongoing travel.The friendly atmosphere and group meals are served to you by your host. Kannur beach can be treacherous so check out the undertow before entering the sea.

Review_Title: “Owner Has Checked Out//Major Construction Next Door”
Review_Content: We stayed here for three nights on the recommendation of a friend who had visited several years ago. Our main interest was attending a Theyyam which the owner arranged for us and which was fascinating. HOWEVER; Kurian; the owner has simply checked on this property...he has two others....and leaves a young kid (about 16 years old I would say) in charge. The kid is clearly overwhelmed. The food is adequate Keralan cuisine; nothing exceptional; and we stayed a total of two months in Kerala so we have a pretty good idea of how excellent Keralan cuisine can be. The place is not particularly clean or well maintained. A sign of the owner's indifference to this enterprise is the decrepit outdoor furniture that is straggled around the property and the absence of any hammocks along the property's stunningly beautiful frontage along a sea side cliff. In contrast; the owner's own property; where he lives; is beautifully maintained and charming. And has wireless which this property does not. Anybody considering a visit anytime anytime soon should also be aware that there is a MAJOR construction project going on immediately next door right next to the outdoor dining room. The noise was so great from the project site that we had to get up and eat on the other side of the property during one luncheon (they were pouring concrete on Sunday.)We were disappointed enough in this place to check out the competition and found a small hotel called the Waves Beach Resort; which is a five minute walk away. It was recently constructed; has the same spectacular view; and an energetic young owner anxious to please who speaks excellent English. Her energy and ambition contrast very favorably with the burned out; slothful indifference of Casa Malabari. The prices were about 20% less also. Their rooms were clean with excellent bathrooms and some had beautiful ocean views. We did not sample the cooking but they offer three meals a day.Anyway; we would not return to Casa Malabari and would check out other options were we to come back.

This was our least favorite homestay during our nearly 3 week trip to Kerala; and I am mystified by all the positive reviews. The only thing that was positive about our stay was the magnificent view of the Arabian sea - that is why I did not give it 1 star. (Make sure if you do stay here - that this is the building you stay in).This homestay is clearly coasting on its laurels. The owner; who has 3 buildings in the area; was nowhere to be found for most of our stay; and left the day to day operations to a 17 year old boy who clearly needed more supervision. Meals were often served a half an hour after the designated time. Even something simple like getting a cup of coffee or tea would take 20 or more minutes (plus another 10 minutes to get non-sour milk).Most importantly; the place is not being maintained properly - water pressure was on and off (one night there was no water at all) and it was not clean. The beams in our room were patched up with ugly packing tape. The mosquito net our bed was provided with was full of holes; making it useless. To get wireless internet; you have to walk fifteen minutes through the woods to the owner's other property (though we didn't really care about that - other travelers might).Despite the wonderful view; the owner has not done any landscaping to speak of; and the back yard facing the ocean is basically a dirt lot with a few trees and several broken; filthy; uncomfortable beach chairs. Repairs are not being made - even minor ones like fixing unsightly broken wooden slats in the outdoor eating area. Our last day here was basically ruined by loud construction work taking place immediately next door (where a new home is being built). We were never offered any sort of discount or anything extra.The overall impression is that the owner just doesn't care about this place. And the sad thing is; with a little effort; this could be a truly wonderful homestay. Apparently; there is a new homestay down the road from Costa Malabari. We didn't stay there but I think that a little competition is exactly what this place needs.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Make sure everything is working and that there is water pressure in your room!

Review_Content: We stayed here for a days last week and Kurian was soo helpful with ordering autos and cars and very helpful in getting us to a Theyyam at 5am! Food was absolutely delicious with fresh fruit juice and puddings. Rooms very clean and comfortable. Beach was beautiful and all but empty. Hand loom factory was very interesting and close by. Definitely worth a stay!

Costa Malabari was a great place to stay. Fantastic staff. Food we are still dreaming about. Great way to meet other travellers. Wonderful room. Mozzie screens on windows. In a private and quiet location away from Kunnar. Close to beach. Lots of birds. Very helpful in getting us to a Theyyam.

We checked in here after a stay at their sister property Elim Homestay in Kochi. Rooms are housed in a couple of different buildings; but we stayed in a nice room in the old handloom factory. Everyone eats breakfast; lunch and dinner (which are included in the price) on a long table down the middle of the big communal dining room. It was a nice atmosphere and you got to chat to lots of other visitors in quite a intimate setting. The nearby beaches (make sure to venture beyond the big beach to little hidden coves) are stunning and you'll probably have them to your self. The food is definitely a highlight (dinner thalis served on banana leafs!) and Kurion who runs the place is the ultimate fixer - organizing rickshaws and finding out train and bus times. It's worth checking out a Theyyam whilst you're here too. All the staff were very hospitable - we booked in for 4 days and have stayed a week. We've got some pictures and a write up on our blog...http://alongnicewalk.tumblr.com

we stayed here for a few nights with our 3 & 5 year olds. We had the place to ourselves as it was monsoon. It didn't rain all the time but when it did rain; this was not a problem. The problem was the stairs down to the beach. basically the house is on a cliff with the beach below and they have erected a metal staircase down from the cliff to the beach. But it is one of the scariest staircases I have ever used. There is a very serious drop onto rocks if you were to slip from the staircase and there is only a high hand rail. There are no barriers between the handrail and the stairs; so it is completely open. I would have a problem with this stair case even without children. It is a deathtrap waiting to happen. they only need to put bars in so that no one could fall through this huge gap and it would be ok. But they have not thought of safety here. That said the beach is very beautiful. the house and rooms are very basic and the garden is terrible and not cared for. The people who look after you at the house and do the cooking are lovely and the food is very good. As there was no one else staying we asked if our children could sleep in the room next to ours rather on the camp beds in our room and they let us do this and did not charge extra. There are 2 places in Kannur to choose from and if we went back we would stay at Kannur Beach House; which is right on the beach. Costa Malabari is in a very tranquil place and you are basically trapped here unless you pay; 150 for a rickshaw. I think this place (the area; not the house) would be lovely during the summer but the staircase is still a massive problem.

Review_Title: “Private and peaceful little sanctuary minutes from the beach”
Review_Content: Although I travelled to Costa Malabari during monsoon and it rained for almost 5 days straight; this private and peaceful guesthome truly gave my companion and I a very warm and welcoming experience. The staff is very kind and accomodating. Kurion; your main point person is phenomenal. He thoroughly explains the history of Theyyam (historical dance ritual) among many other things. He is a great resource and is well travelled throughout India and can help you with any questions you may have. Costa Malabari I can say with confidence provided the best food we have had in India. Kurion was more than willing to share various cooking secrets for traditional meals from Kerala. The facilties are simple; but very clean and all functioning. Except for the odd power outage due to the rains; the place really was a safe haven from the hustle and bustle of the city streets. It is nestled away in a wooded; coconut forest/grove close to the beach and is situated in a very picturesque part of Kannur. The area is great for long walks where you get a really nice feel for culture. Excellent accomodation; excellent value.

You know you're onto a winner in India if all you can hear is birdsong. This tranquil haven offers sublime home cooked food and a gracious host ensures your every whim is catered for. A small deserted beach is a 5 minute walk away; but sadly no swimming; the sea is so ferocious that even a paddle could sweep you away. My room was nicely furnished and cool; the communal eating area is a great place to get to know your fellow guests - and yes it's embarrassingly cheap to stay here.

We spent a very relaxing two nights at Costa Malabari. We stayed in main house in an immaculately clean room with A/C (pleasant surprise). Bed mats were foamy topped making them softer than the usual hard India bed.Beach was beautiful and basically deserted. As promised only five minute walk away.Loved the homecooked meals - good variety for lunch and dinner. Breakfast of omlette and toast a bit boring by day three but filling. Nice to visit with other travelers at communal meals.Transpor to Theyyam for performance arranged easily.Great place to unwind for a few days!!

Review_Title: “lovely place to relax in a hectic country”
Review_Content: Clean simple room; a wonderful bech close at hand and food to die for. Whats more to ask of a place? Oh yes at 1200 Rs. per person it´s a bargain.

I could not recommend the location of Costa Malabari 2 enough. The beach is superb and quiet but an eventful climb down (the new staircase was not finished when we were there). Watching the fisherman swimming to shore to carry up the catch of the day for us to eat that night; brings a whole new meaning to fresh. Food great and flavoursome and they could not be more helpful and arranged a trip to a local temple. Accommodation is clean and all you need but could not be called luxurious; but you only sleep in your room so not necessary.

Excellent hotel. Make sure you stay at the location perched on a cliff; The other my friends tell me(the one without the beach view) is not as nice. Keralite food is excellent and beautifully served. The view is superb and Kurien is helpful witht he theyyam information.

fantastic place; delicious food; great service; perfect place for meeting other travellers. there are no shops and not that many other places to stay around here but costa malabari maintains a really high standard and they seem to know what travellers want instinctively. the beach is pristine; pretty much deserted and undeveloped; a wonderful place. the theyyam was cool too.
we stayed at Costa Malabari for 2 nights only but I wish we could have stayed longer. The setting is beautiful; the manager very hospitable but most of all I remember the food - delicious!

My girlfriend and I have spent 2 nights in the main house; a former weaving workshop. This is 5 minutes walk from the coast; 20 minutes walk from paradise hidden beaches; either north or south. We were actually delighted to walk; having spent so many hours in trains or rickshaws over the last weeks... The surroundings are very residential at a very low density; hence we felt in the middle of nowhere and enjoyed taking all the meals in the house. It costs 1250 Rs per person inc. 3 meals and filtered water. In Costa Malabari indeed; this drinking water solution is the best option for the environment.There were 4 rooms and all 8 guests had meals together. A great opportunity to share traveller's stories. Food was excellent and in large quantities.The manager Kieran was very helpful. He organised a visit to a local temple where a small theyyam ritual was taking place. He also booked a room for us at a partner hotel (Pachyderm Palace) in Wayanad and explained everything for us to go by bus; the cheapest way!Also very useful is the Internet connexion; with a desktop computer that guests can use any time and for free.The only difficulty we had was with the advance booking. Tourist Desk Kochi was not really eager to answer emails and was very silly to request a transfer in Roupies from foreigners. We ignored that request and simply confirmed by email and on the phone a few days in advance. A bit of a stressful experience during the peak season.From other travellers; I heard this is amongst the cheapest of the numerous coastal guest houses around. I also heard they have been recommended in Lonely Planet for more than 5 years.

Review_Title: “Hidden oasis from the organised Chaos that is India”
Review_Content: We found this place thanks to the Lonley Planet; and thank the lord we did find this place. We thought it was one of the best places we had stayed in so far in India. the owner is a very friendly and welcoming man who is always willing to help out with the organistation of buses or trains or even the world class trip to see the 'Theeyam'.Our room was spacious; and came with a mosquito net and fly netting on the windows. The beds were comfortable and a good length. The room had a good supply of hot water; so a nice lenghty shower in the morning was a great luxuary to have.The food was excellent and plentiful; we were pleasently suprised with the quality of the meals. There is free internet which can be very temprimental; and also free wi-fi which is nice to have to catch up with emails and skype etc.Kannur town itself is farily uninteresting but the jewel in the crown for Costa Malabari is that its a couple of mins walk from the most amazing beach; empty; beautiful and peaceful. What a place this is!

Costa malabari is a friendly guesthouse in the forest; 5 minutes from desert beaches. Many backpackers pass here and there is a great atmosphere...we spent every night chatting with the other guests and taking a break from the chaotic India.The room is simple and clean and the staff is super friendly. Don't miss Theyyam!!Also food is great and we definitely recommend especially if you are a backpacker!

Stayed at the house on the sea cliff for four nights. Room was very clean. Food was great! Our host spent time with us every night of our stay and provided us with great insights into Indian family life and values. Host arranged sightseeing trips for us to Beedi & hand weaving factories and to a beautiful Hindu temple over 2000 years old.Great value!!

Review_Title: “If it's Theyyam you're after; can't go wrong”
Review_Content: There are a couple of better but similarly priced options around if you’re just after a relaxing time by the beach; but if it’s Theyyam you’re after then this does what it says in the guidebooks and doesn’t disappoint. The manager knows his coconuts with the Theyyams and will arrange transport to and from the temples where performances are taking place. A genial chap; provides as much information and help as you’re after without imposing himself on you. We stayed at the main house (not the one above the beach) which had a pleasant atmosphere of similarly minded travellers looking to probe a little deeper into the region’s traditions. Food’s good and plentiful; rooms are pretty basic but clean. Expensive for India; although so are the other places in the area.

There are actually 3 heritage houses that make up Costa Malabari and we stayed at number 2 which is right above a virtually private beach.The rooms are simple but clean; the food is excellent (all meals included) and the area is unspoilt and beautiful.We stayed a week to soak it all in.Kurien; who runs it; is a gracious host with impeccable local contacts and we saw two Theyam rituals during our stay.If you want a really lazy stay on a beach; without endless hassle; then this is it.Superb.

This is a place not to be missed. We stayed in Costa Malabari 2 which is on a cliff top overlooking a palm fringed sandy beach. The guest house has its own precipitous steps so you can get to and from the beach in swim suits thus not offending local sensibilities. The four rooms are basic but comfortable (fan cooled). Food is eaten communally so everyone gets chatting. Kannur has a really good fort and the fishing harbour is worth a visit when they unload the catch (town centre is some distance away). The manager is a friendly and erudite man who willingly gives his time to make your stay enjoyable.

This is the place where to stay in the Malabar Coast. Tucked away on the sea cliffs in between villages; it is secluded enough to provide access to several good beaches; not crowded and sandy. Rooms are spartan but building is charming and with nice garden. Food is exceptionally good; varied and abundant. All meals are served with other guests and atmosphere is pleasant and relaxing. Very good value for money. When you get bored to be too relaxed; short trips can be organized easily and are worthwhile; ranging from ancient forts on the sea to traditional dances in villages - owner is an expert and everything is arranged smoothly.

Costa Malabari was the third stop on our two-week backpacking trip from Goa to Kochi. Kannur itself is nothing to talk about - we didn't actually do anything other than drive through the town. We stayed at the house on top of the cliff overlooking the beach. If you do go - this location is MUCH better than the other Costa Malabari House. I would also recommend the upstairs bedroom. There is not much to do around Costa Malabari except read; relax; lay on the beach; swim; and watch Theyyam. If you are looking for a good place to do those things (which we were) then it's a great place. The beach is nothing short of phenomenal. The food was great (but not the best in Kerala - as Lonely Planet suggests) and your hosts aim to please. The only suggestion I have is for chairs on the beach.

Dear traveller;This is a real place to stop by and stay for a couple of days relaxing.We were backpacking; had some trouble to find it; but arrived there; it was the most beautiful; quiet place we've stopped by.We could enjoy private beaches; had great guidance by the charmful home stay manager (theyyams) and enjoyed the home made served breakfasts; dinner and lunches...Please enjoy !Ronald & Karlien

Review_Title: “This is the place to go for untouched beaches!”
Review_Content: Stayed here for two weeks because we enjoyed it so much. The rooms are pretty basic; but comfy and clean; hot water in the shower; and the clean them as much as you like. The host Kurian is a very nice fellow; and he's backed up by an excellent staff. The food is among the best I've had in India; no doubt; fish curries for two weeks - although it makes you yearn for meat. Three meals a day is really worth the 1250 you pay per day.The nearby beaches are paradise; shared only with some fishermen and the ocassional stroller. If I knew about this place I would drop Goa. This was a real gem; a nice place to meet fellow travelers and exchange emails and tips for the ongoing journey of India.

This is truly a lovely place. Costa Malabari used to be a weaving workshop which has been reformed as a homestay. The rooms and facilities are basic but confortable and tastfully decorated (in an understated way). There is no A/C; Pool etc; so if you want extra confort this is not the place for you.For us It was a perfect spot to unwind; read; eat well and rest.  You can walk to 5 beaches; all of them beautiful and seldom visited (we were there in September) so you really feel like you are on your own which is very rare in india!All the food is provided and it is fabulous. They spend hours preparing the meals and it shows; plus you can always go into the kitchen and learn to cook yourself.Kurian; the host; was really helpful and was often around for a chat after dinner. Our conversations with him are some of our most valued memories from the trip; as he provided us with a lot of information and context about India which we would't have had otherwise.Other than that there is no much else to do around other than going into town and see a teyyam performance or Kalaripayattu; but this was welcomed after 2 weeks of manic travelling around Kerala.

Kurian is the person around whom everything revolves here; and he sits with you while you eat at most of the meals and talks to you; sometimes at you; about life around here. He can arrange for you to go to a Theyyam event at a local temple; and is a very courteous helpful host. The food is fantastic. One of us is vegetarian; and it was a marvel how the cook; who seems to spend all day preparing the food; is able to conjure up new meals three times a day. The place itself is very basic; and there is not much around; though there was some building work going on nearby; which would give a different feel to what is now quite an isolated place. You walk about ten minutes to get to the deserted beach. There is a little rubbish around from the tiny village near the beach; but actually it is quite clean around. My partner; who does Yoga saw a mongoose and babies running around; and I caught sight of one near the beach. If you just want to sit around and relax and read and eat and sleep; then this the place! There were gathering winds and rain in April while we were there; and it would be perhaps a bit noisy and annoying if there were too many other guests; but it is still worth a go; and is an experience.

I LOVED IT. Sweet simple and intimate place with a private beach. The owner; Mr Kurian; is so helpful and kind. He helped every guest with all aspects of their itineraries. He was also an expert on Theyyanm and helped us find celebrations to attend.It as the best food that we had in India - we did not want to miss a meal. We ate outside; listening to the ocean nearby. The staff were all friendly and wonderfu. I hope to go back sometime in my life.

We stayed 2 nights at this delightful off the beaten track homestay and found it ideal for complete relaxation at the end of our 2 week travels in Southern India. Room was basic but clean and more than adequate. - not the most comfortable bed we`ve encountered in India but not the worst! Stunning location just steps down from the garden to a beautiful deserted beach. Our charming resident host/cook served us absolutely delicious Keralan food - lots of variety over the 2 days we were there.

Stayed 10 days at the Costa Malabari in November 2007; as part of our honeymoon. We were desperately sad to leave. It's basic; that's true; but the location is stunning; the staff are wonderful; and the food is great (although it does get a little samey after a week or so). Can't comment on the price; probably pricey by Indian standards; but we never felt ripped off in any way.

A wonderful place. Nothing fancy; just simple and good. This is the place to go to watch Theyam! Mr. Kurien arranges all and is passionate and knowledgeable about the dances. He is a delight; as are the two people who cook and serve the meals. Communal table made for new friendships. It's definitely off the beaten path and is not a good place for people who need lots of distractions or high end treatment. But I'll return some day for the great swimming beach right below the house; with nothing else to do during the day but sit and watch the Arabian Sea and Theyam in the early morning hours! Definitely one of the highlights of our month in India.

Costa Malabari is hailed by a number of \independent\" travel guides how great it is. The only outstanding thing about it is the location -very close to the beach (but you should explore further afield) and potentially close to theyyam locations. I was surprised that food is mentioned at all in any of the guides; or my any of the travelers - awfully bland and same every of the 4 days we stayed there! Kurian; the manager; is a nice educated man but lost interest in the enterprise years ago; although he is welcoming; and informative - but only when asked. Rooms are decent but not cleaned one time we were there; and communal space limited. Theyyam information might as well be obtained from anybody else - taxi and rickshaw drivers. Overall not good value for money at 2500rs for a couple. You can easily stay more comfortably in any of the dozens or so homestays within walking distance. Don’t let LP fool you! Finally; the same travel desk in Kochi runs another \"homestay\" - Pachyderm Palace in Waynard Reserve - much worse than Costa Malabari; crumbling rooms; repetitive food and at the same price as CM even a worse deal. Wayno; the manager; tried hard; but its not easy to make anything out of this place."

We chose to spend 7 nights at Costa Malabari based on the website and the reviews. What we found were two grubby rooms which were not cleaned nor were the rather grim sheets and towels changed until we complained. It most certainly did not look like the photographs. There were cockroaches in the rooms unlike everywhere else we stayed in India. The famous food was the same every day bar one; and again unlike every other homestay we visited was not particularly good. There is very little communal space to sit. The host was not nearly as informative as the local taxi drivers on theyyam and generally not very interested in his guests. There was no Christmas decorations or attempt to do something special for the guests who had flown out especially to celebrate there. It was expensive by Indian standards and was very much a property past its best.

Like most visitors to Costa Malabari we were there for theyyam. The Manager; Mr Kurien; is very happy to share his knowledge & arrange for you to visit a theyyam in the season; and is a welcoming host. It was defintely worth visiting for this alone.Mr Kurien is also very happy to help organise onward travel/flights/rooms; etc. I think he is part-owner of a travel agency.The rooms are simple; but clean on arrival; although no-one cleaned our room during our stay & this was the only place we stayed on our trip where sheets were not changed every day. Light in the room was good enough to read at night. Like others; we also encountered creepy crawlies in the bathroom; but not to an excessive level.The food is very good - proper Keralan home cooking. No choice as such but with so many dishes served at each meal it would be easy to miss out one you didn't like. Bananas and purified water were available freely at any time.There were a few things that we didn't like about Costa Malabari1. Europeans predominate. During our stay everyone was European and if you spent an extended time here it could feel like you were hidden away somewhere in Europe. This was the only place we stayed on our trip where we were not chatting to Indian visitors as well.2. Lack of outside space. There is a big airy communal hall with a dining table to sit at; where people tended to congregate & chat. The latest Lonely Planet says 'lots of comfy lounging areas dot the outside'; but this is complete nonsense. There is virtually no outside space to 'dot'; so everyone is sat on the porch; which has comfortable chairs but is packed in tight so that it feels as if you are on top of one another. 3. Lack of privacy; depending on which rooms you have. The two rooms at the front have windows facing onto the porch where everyone sits outside. If you are in one of these; by 6am there is likely to be someone sat about 2 feet from your bed having what sounds at that time of the morning and proximity like an extremely loud conversation ..... and able to hear every sound you make as well!There is now another Costa Malabari house; perched on a clifftop a few minutes away; with steps down to a beach. We took a quick look and standards appeared to be the same. Here there was no big communal interior; but definitely a bit more space outside.

My party of 8 recently stayed at the property and I can't tell you enough about the wonderful service offered by the people at Costa Malabari. While the rooms were quite basic in nature and played host to everything from scorpions to flying cockroaches; what the rooms lacked in character was more than made up for by the incredible service and food from Mr. Kurrien and his staff. The beach is only about a four minute walk away. The style of the beach house is typical Keralan style with open high beams that encourage constant airflow. I was a bit concerned with not having air conditioning but I needn't have been. We were able to rest comfortably thanks to the fans and open windows. I can't say enough about the food and the huge portions we received. We had everything from fried Baracuda to mussels and chicken biryani. I would recommend this property for anyone looking for a bit of an off the beaten path adventure. It's definitely not a luxury property but is well worth a stay.

After being recommended to visit Costa Malabari by someone who had stayed there for three months we felt his opinions of great food and a homely atmosphere may have been somewhat biased but after visiting for ourselves we realized everything he said was correct. As explained in the previous review the accomodation is spacious and very clean; arranged around a congenial dining hall- which is a great place to sit if you feel like a chat. Although at the top of our budget at Rs2000 a night it is full board and the food really is fantastic. We found it quite hard to sample real Keralan food in restaurants around the state so to experience such high quality home cooking- all served up on a banana leaf was quite special. In terms of local attractions it seems to main reason visitors come to Cannanore is to search out a Theyyam. The owner has a wealth of knowledge on these spectacular rituals which he is more than willing to share with you around the table at supper and if you stay for a few nights you may even be able to see a few. They reach their peak in the early hours of the morning - but a taxi is usually arranged between a group of guests for the journey. As well as visiting the Theyyam's the area is also a fantastic place to explore on foot. It is quite easy to get lost in the coconut groves but with incredibly friendly and hospitable locals this rarely causes too much of a problem. If; of course; you don't feel like doing anything there are 3 deserted beaches 5 minutes from the guest house to swim or sunbathe. Getting to the guest house from Kannur station can be a problem as not all taxi and richshaw drivers know the place. However making a phone booking before can solve this as the owner will happily send a taxi to pick you up. All in all; a real highlight in our trip around India; and even if you are on a really tight budget I would recommend splashing out on this place!

Review_Title: “A great place on the Malabar Coast; northern Kerala”
Review_Content: Costa Malabari; Near Adikadalayi Temple; Kannur; Wayanad District; 670 007 Kerala; IndiaThis marvelous guesthouse in northern Kerala is located on a narrow dirt road a few kilometers from the nearest city; itself an enjoyable place to wander around and easily accessible by bus from the nearby temple. Mr. Kurian; the owner; is the best source for performances of theyyam; an ancient spirit-possession rite that is rife in this area in hundreds of variants. He knows where performances will be taking place and arranges transportation. The other point of interest is the beautiful and nearly deserted beach; a five-minute walk from the guesthouse. Walking on the nearby roads is enjoyable; you might see a mongoose or some curious birds; not to mention friendly local residents. Accommodations--now expanded into nearby cottages as well as the four or five rooms in the main house; each with its own bathroom--are clean and comfortable; the food is topnotch and copious; and the other guests--from various European countries and the U.S. when we were there--are themselves full of interest; with old-timers more than willing to share their knowledge of the locality. Everyone eats together around a long table; and chairs on the porch invite further conversation or quiet reading. We were glad that we had a cell phone with us when our driver; hired to drive our party of four from Kalpetta; was stumped after we got to the area. Mr. Kurian himself met us at the top of the road for reassurance. Book ahead through the tourist desk in Cochin.

ur company is good hotel not bed some minor issues .I am visit in hotel and check in room but Ac is not working .food is good .also room sevice is good .but overall good next time i am touch with you.

I never knew that this Hotel was out of business for a year and only opened in the month of October 2012 and I was scheduled to stay in this hotel in the month of November 2012.Though the new management had taken this hotel there was no significant investment to renovate.The first I was offered was a deluxe a/c with a broken COT; later got changed to another room with a COT which was not broken but with a bathroom which did not have option of running hot water.The whole property was stinking; there was this foul smell which is due to lack of ventilation.To make things worst the first evening we were tired and badly needed a good sleep; unfortunate the hotel owner's daughter was getting married and there was a bachelor party arranged at the ground floor of the hotel for their family guests and BOOZE and DANCE with some dirty numbers continued till 03:00 AM and the height was no one in reception to listen to our complaint.I only realized in the morning that the only guest in that hotel was me and my family :(STRICTLY AVOIDABLE is the only tag line this hotel should carry.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Get into this hotel only if you do not have any choice

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: Nice views from the room. Decent food; and a value for money too. But I don't think the rooms are worth their price (even though I wen't there in the off season and got a discount). But it seems like the best hotel around this place.

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: Gmvn hotel was clean and on a very good location. We enjoyed the stay but the food was not at all good. The money we paid for food was waste. Better to eat out. I recommend rooms with balcony facing the river and mountain it is beautiful.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Rooms with balcony facing the river and mountain is the best.

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: Nice Location for Weekend Tour; specially for Elder Person as well as the nature lover. Cool and Calm Locality. Good Food Quality and Room Service! Waiting for Next Visit. Recommend for a great weekend tour.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Riverside Cottages are good.

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: We planned a weekend trip to some hill station so we drove all the way to Syalsaur .We stayed at GMVN guest house; Syalsaur from 1 June -2 June 2013. The place was good. Just next to river and in the middle of all the greenery . Had lot of fun. This is one of the best place to escape from daily life and recharge yourself

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: Somethings you want to keep a secret so not all go and spoil it.But I am sure many of you know it in this age of net about finest most romantic blissful river side stay one can imagine>Next in completion would be next door spot called Chandrapuri all Aluminium cottages on the banks of blue river of immense beauty Mandakini coming from Khatling glacier as you make your way up towards Kedarnath from Rudraprayag.Other one is Kaudiyala bamboo cottages 27 kms from Rishikesh on badrinath road.These are places where you are close to Ganga and yet in cheapest lap of luxury which private resorts cannot compete in location and prices.Want to write a book.get away from it all..be together doing 'nothing' these are the spots on river side stays divine!But this one Syalsaur has been made by some one who is truely proud of what Uttaranchal esp Garhwal western part of this Great dev bhoomi offers.Himalayas snow capped peaks on the horizon as you sit on the rocks as blue river flows by.You get all the food and stay comforts and both these spots we used as stops to relax before and after the trek up the Tungnath 3890 meters and then kedarnath 3 day stay up in 3300 meters when i took my family to Only Mandakini river voyage kedarnath journey.Go without shouting about this place;stay for two days and find bliss..or rest as you climb up /down the heights of kedarnath at a price no one will offer other than GMVNL.Thanks.All wooden cottages are made up wood even in the bathroom and have two bed rooms.All are named after all great branches which makes up river ganges.We stayed in mandakini cottage.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: For peace and quit only revelers please avoid this place for Others who want it.All cottages are gre...

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: On our recent driving holiday in the Garhwal Himalayas we had planned to drive from Rishikesh to Joshimath following the rivers path. Instead of staying at Rudraprayag we decided to drive on to Syal Saur about 27 Km upriver on the Mandakini. In hindsight; this was an excellent decision.The GMVN Resort in Syal Saur is located on the Mandakini riverside and you can walk out from your cottage and actually tip-toe in the river!! The view of the river and the surrounding mountain range is simply gorgeous!! You have a variety of birds residing at the resort itself! It is a treat to watch these beauties.The cottages are very tastefully furnished and decorated;using bamboo in various forms.We were the only guests since February is quite cold and considered \off-season\". However the lone caretaker Deepakwas very helpful and hospitable. He really looked after us and provided delicious food. He was on call; and would quickly conjure up steaming hot cups of tea accompanied by irresistable pakodas.Though power cuts were frequent as is usual in Uttarakhand;he ensured that the generator backup started as soon as possible. We were very very comfortable despite a heavy downpour on one of the 3 days we spent there.We made day trips to Ukhimath and Guptkashi from here.The scenery on the drives is fantastic; though the road is quite rough and demanding.This is one place that I would love to come back to."
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Choose a cottage on the rivers edge; the view is heavenly.

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: it is located right on the river mandakini which is enough good point for the believers . Add to that the surroundings which are beautiful and peaceful ... one feels that one can stay for a couple of days and relax/ meditate/introspect/rejuvenate . Simple food ; simple rooms ; ok service but don't expect much from the management ; because ; for any problem they can get away with out doing any thing simply by quoting the interior location . Good place but keep your expectations low .

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: GMVN has properties of varying standards and this is one of the best and I guess one of the least known. Its spread over a 10 acre grounds right alonside the Mandakini river; and is an ideal halt if you are traveling to kedarnath.The rooms are styled like self contained cottages; with all basic facilities. Very clean and reasonably priced ( Rs 1800 for a double room with taxes in October)

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: Right on the banks of Mandakini; mostly made up of bamboo huts which provide an atmosphere which concrete walls cannot provide; the accomodation is great hideaway to disconnect from the rest of the world and re-connect with any other option. The manager is young and friendly; as are his staff; willing to be flexible and adjust as per need. You will wonder why you have to leave.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: on the banks of Mandakini; naturally

Hotel_Name_City: Gmvn Tourist Rest House, Syalsaur Rudra_Prayag
Review_Content: This was one of the best hotels we stayed in Uttarakhand. It is completely wood made individual cottage rooms and everything inside it is wood made. It is located on the banks for the river Mandakini with amazing views. Food is good too. Heater and geyser facilities are not available but you will get a bucket of hot water whenever you need for bath. We loved the experience. It is right on the highway to Kedarnath. A must place to stay in Uttarakhand.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Ask for hot water buckets for bath. Checkout the nice guavas hanging on trees. Dont miss the river v...

Review_Title: “DONT EXPECT MUCH..bt gud enough if u can adjust !”
Review_Content: Stayed der jst fr 1ngt 10oct 14 // pre booked classic deluxe room on yatra.com but hotel tried to give executive room( lower category and very small). Had I not objected wud have to settle fr same..was den shifted to room category which I paid for room 103 // reception was ok nd chk in was fast. Staff doesn't hover which is good. Donot expect coutesy as staff not trained for same so not there fault. washroom lock dsnt works( u mgt end up getting locked in !)Washroom blind dsnt works and was merely hanging with lot of DUCTAPE so hmmm..Had some trouble with running water as no water pressure to take a shower. All in all ok budget .full stop
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Check the rooms first before paying // U mgt get shocked with room size so avoid Blind booking

Review_Content: This time classic dissapoints me; i always loved to visit this whenever i wanted an outing my destination place to get refreshed was classic.But this time it was worst exp. Air conditioned was not working as expected. Refrigerator was not innworking condition; i complaint them too but no reaction was from the staff. Outside my room; there were noises whole night. Some other room guys n gals were making it n i was unable to sleep.My personal advice : please go through the room before booking.Overall it was \adjust to stay\"."

Review_Title: “EXELENT HOTEL IN CHANDIGRAH AND SERVICE ALSO”
Review_Content: Very Nice Hotel.Well behaved and warm staff.Excellent place to relax;spend time and enjoy pleasure moments.Do visit THE HOTEL.Nice place situated in chandigarh.Well maintained surroundings.Food and service excellentservice provide by MR SHARMA
Room_Tips: Room Tip: DELUXE ROOMGOOD ROOM\Higher floors have less A/C unit noise"

Review_Content: Very Nice Hotel.Well behaved and warm staff.Excellent place to relax;spend time and enjoy pleasure moments.Do visit the Hotel.Nice place situated in chandigarh.Well maintained surroundings.Food and service excellent
Room_Tips: Room Tip: All Rooms are Good

Review_Content: i stayed in this hotel in 1st weak of july during my trip to chamdigarh with my familyawsome stay owsome hospitility excelent room service good tasty punjabi food thanx MR RAKESH SHARMA MANAGER who make our stay memmorablble awsome by providing best service and hospitility front office staff is very niceit gives gud value for money; perfect central location.overall gud hotel to stay in. will def recommend it to all.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: \Rooms on the south side are quieter\"\"centraly located hotel best for family and co..."

Review_Content: i stayed 2 nyts in dis hotel what i observed is that yeah it was a valu for money at front desk 2 people one was Mr happy singh(i guess) was v helpfull rooms were worthy neat n clean n had good interior as wellyea best place for famalies;solo;couple but food i did'nt like at all.one problem they do not provide pick up facilty which is lacking. the location is very good for the outsiders who come to see dis city planning to visit chd again in this july hope CLASSIC meet u soon :)

past 2 years everytime i travel to chd this is where i stay. it gives gud value for money; perfect central location; lotsa eating options right next door; gud comfortable rooms and bathrooms; decent service and food. overall gud hotel to stay in. will def recommend it to all.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: go for their suite; its well within the budget and comfy n worth it.

Review_Content: Booked this hotel online for 2 days. I have been travelling to Chandigarh from last 3 months as i have switched my job. Thought of writing this review because i really did not like the hotel BAD service OKAY food. Will not recommend. :(
Room_Tips: Room Tip: More nice options are available in Chandigarh.

Review_Content: We stayed for two nights whilst returning from Manali. Hotel is typical city hotel for budget travellers. Lot of eateries around. Could easily get autos for Chandigarh sight seeing. The room was clean and decent. We had breakfast in the hotel on both the mornings and it was good as well....Overall a nice experience. ...

Review_Title: “Good Location and OK for an overnight stay!”
Review_Content: We have actually stayed at this property twice and looking forward to our 3rd stay this month.Chandigarh happens to be the perfect place for a stop over at night on the way to the hills.Our reason for staying here is the value for money factor which is an important consideration for an overnight stay.The best thing about this hotel is the location and the food options available around this property.Do ensure that you try out the eateries in the vicinity.Rooms are clean and well appointed.Choose lower floor rooms if senior citizens are travelling.
Response_to_Review: Dear Sir;Thanks for taking time out to review us on tripadvisor. We are glad that you liked the overall hotel feel and the quality of our rooms and service.Please feel free to call me and book next time you are traveling to Chandigarh. We look forward to welcoming you back with us.RegardsRakesh Sharma98761 33144

Review_Content: This is a good hotel for medium budgettravellers. We (02 adults + 2 kids 6;10yrs) stayed here as a one night stopover in a twin sharing a/c room. The rooms are quite big & cleanliness is maintained. Breakfast is complementary; but has a fixed plate menu of south-indian preparations only.Had dinner from the outlet 'Maya' which serves traditional Mangalorean dishes. Chicken poollimoonchi was tasty and spicy. Absolutely divine!!!! Price was a bit exorbitant. It was a pleasant stay.

a decent place to stay when on a short trip to mangalore. the sports bar (or whatever t is) is a nice place to have a private party with friends; and for the youth. the chicken ghee roast is quite good there. Had been there to attend my friend's promotion party

As the title suggests the hotel is a decent place to stay in the heart of the city. The room and the bathroom were clean. The furniture could be arranged in a better way so as to avoid any inconvenience to the guests. The room we stayed in was road facing and we could hear the sound of traffic. The breakfast at the hotel was good and made-to-order. The price is not exorbitant. In total it was worth the money spent.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Avoid the road facing rooms if you are a light sleeper.

Review_Content: I stayed here for two days on a business trip. The rooms are quite big & cleanliness is maintained. But beyond this; I have faced a lot of problems. - The rooms facing the road are well-lit & ventilated; but very noisy. The a/c does not cool the room properly. The mattress & linen is worn-out and needs replacement. - Food options for vegetarians are very limited (cannot comment on non-veg preparations). Request for non-oily & non-spicy food did not have much effect. - One cannot get even a cup of tea before 7am as restaurant/room service starts at 7am! Similarly evening service starts at 7pm.- Breakfast is complementary; but has a fixed plate menu of south-indian preparations only. The breakfast is supposed to start at 7am. However; I had an early checkout on last day; but it was not ready at 7.15am.- To top it all; on my checkout; I noticed a discrepancy in my main bill & supportings for room service. But the receptionist insisted that the bill was correct & I have to pay-up. After an argument for 15 min the hotel manager was called; and it was found out that the receptionist had not attached all supportings with the bill; as some were still lying in the bill-folder!!

Review_Title: “Decent Stay but the Service is great!”
Review_Content: Stayed here for work; was my first time travel on work; the door latch was broken and I didnt sleep one whole night. The next morning I informed the house-keeping about the inconvenience and they were more than apologetic for the same. Maya serves a blend of pure Mangalorean cuisine and other cuisines. The Fish Fry is absolutely divine!!!! Great place to stay...
Room_Tips: Room Tip: Openly communicate your preferences at the reception and they will be more than willing to serve you...

Review_Content: I stayed with my family. This is the 3rd visitto this hotel. The rooms are very big.The reception very good. The breakfastis nice. The room service needs to be improved. House keeping ok.This is a good hotel for medium budgettravellers.Room Tip;- Avoid rooms below dance hall in 4th floor.

We stayed in this hotel last month in the Suite called the Mangala Penthouse which consisted of 3 rooms with attached bathrooms and huge living room; dining room and a kitchen.The rooms were clean and big; though the bathrooms needed to be cleaned when we checked in and even after the cleaning they were not excellent but functional and clean.The plumbing was also not very great. The staff was very friendly; the morning breakfast was very good except for the Upma. The Medu wadas and Dosas though were excellent.They do have a very weird position for the TVs in the room though; they are placed very low on the wall under the windows.Also the rooms seemed to have excessive curtains; as it has tints on it's windows; plus some 3 layers of curtains and they did not open. SO needed the lights on even during the day.Also the kitchen only had a fridge; no gas stove or microwave which would have been handy since they do not have room service or any snacks etc available after 11pm.Also the discotheque in the floor below is open even during the day and in the night; so the living room tends to feel the vibrations but the rooms are peaceful.Over all; it was a good palce to stay; and as we were there for a wedding; it became a nice party pad for all of us due to the huge living room .
Room_Tips: Room Tip: If you are a group of 6 or more; it definitely makes sense to book the penthouse.

Review_Content: Went for a trip to Mangalore during the last week of September. Had a nice stay in Maya International. Nice and spacious rooms. Their service needs to improve a bit though. They provide complimentary breakfast but not that great. Overall; it is a nice place to stay.

We went to hotel on 25th night after tiresome journey of about 250kms from kumta. We had actually planned to checkin to vaibhav international but seeing the pathetic condition we changed to naveen residency. When we called the hotel to enquire on the way; they asked us to comeup and see the hotel rooms and decide. We came to hotel which is in the service road of NH4 and found quite better than vaibhav and took the room. Room was quite comfortable and ac noiseless. Staff quite obliging and reception desk quite warmth. Breakfast complimentary was adequate. A multi cuisine restaurant is there at the backyard of the hotel in a big hall and a garden. Rate is quite reasonable. Quite a convenient place to stay while visiting historical fort; chandragiri cave and jogi matti.

Review_Title: “Decent breakfast; dirty ambience and uninterested service”
Review_Content: This place is on the Bengaluru-Mumbai highway and I have stopped here a few times for breakfast and lunch whilst enroute. Honestly; the food is ok. They do not serve a variety of dishes for breakfast but only idli; vadas and dosas (the in house guests are served the same buffet style which you can also opt for; for a per head fee). For lunch I'd recommend the South Indian thali. But it is the dirty tables that makes me cringe. Leftover food bits from previous meal or the people who have used the table before you is a common sight. A request to clean the table means that the waiter will make a face and sweep half of the crumbs on the floor and ignore you when you request for the rest of the table to be cleaned. I guess that as they are assured of patrons; thanks to their convenient location of being situated right on the highway; they do not care about the service they provide. Also; they push you into buying mineral water here by not serving regular filtered water. Upon asking to be served filtered water they behave as if they've not heard you but a request for bottled water is serviced within minutes. But; they have a clean loo that you can use. And that is A BIG attraction while travelling. I am sure that if another restaurant came up on the highway with better service; food and a LOO Naveen will lose clients in a jiffy.

During our visit to Chitradurga Fort; we had stayed in this hotel for one day. We had booked deluxe suite. I feel the rate is a bit on the higher side compared to the size of the room and facilities provided. The Suite room is small and since this hotel is just opposite to the national highway; there is a lot of noise during night. Complimentary breakfast was okay. Anyway manageable for one night stay. Free wi-fi did not function properly. Good parking area.

We halted in this hotel during our trip from Bangalore to Goa. Was getting late in the evening and the next stop being fair distance away; we decided to make a night stay here. Prices appeared high for a highway side hotel; but knowing there wouldn't be many options in that small town; we decided to give it a shot. On inspection; the rooms looked good; parking was adequate; appeared safe and the hotel staff friendly. A bit of Indian concept \a bit of bargaining is never bad\" helped me convince the manager to offer a corporate discount. That sealed the deal for me.As said; the room was BIG; good; the AC was actually working and had a clean washroom. To be true; i expected none from these. We had a house help travelling with us; and they happily gave him a nice comfy place to sleep (at no extra cost). Internet was free and had decent speed. I was overwhelmed by now but things didn't end here.Food was really good and they also arranged for milk and customised chapattis for our 1yr old baby. Service was equally prompt and courteous. I couldn't ask for more. We had a really comfortable and relaxed sleep to be ready for taking up the next leg of our journey.A certain recommendation if you visit this nondescript town of Chitradurga and end up staying there."
Room_Tips: Room Tip: take up a room which opens toward their lawn. Gives you an awesome view of the highway and the town...

Review_Content: We stopped here for lunch. For south Indian thali it was overpriced. You can have continental food in other restaurants for same price. Tables were not cleaned properly. Food tasted average.Wash rooms should be more tidy.

This place sits bang midway between Chennai - Goa or Coimbatore - Goa. The accommodation is OK; the rooms are clean; the toilets could be cleaner. The staff service is really good; the food is great. I would stay again if traveling this route.

Location on the highway is convenient. The bed is as small as the beds I've used in Japan. The double bed is just sufficient for 2 people to sleep without any movement. Bathroom also awfully small in the shower area. Food was good.

We spent a night at Hotel Naveen Regency in Dec. We had pre booked a non AC room a few days before. The reservation process (telephonic) was simple and hazzle free. Ample parking space available. I found the staff friendly. The room that we stayed on the 3rd floor was clean. Toilets were good. No issues whatsoever. We loved the food that we had ordered. Complimentary Breakfast was just about OK. the hotel is around 3 kms from the fort and on the service lane of NH4.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: The rooms that we stayed was on the 3rd floor. Comfortable no problems whatsoever.

Review_Content: We stopped at hotel Naveen not expecting much expecting a place to stay the night and some decent food. I must say that the room looked clean. The walls show obvious signs of repair; but then it is repaired so that is good. The bathroom is clean enough even though the light above the sink did not work. The saddest thing was their food: Upon looking at their menu; my mouth started watering; but unfortunately; they had nothing that I wanted. We checked in at 3:00pm and were asked if we wanted coffee or tea. The tea was tasty but then I always drink mine cold. The coffee was cold too.When I asked them for something from their afternoon menu; all they had was Khara bhaath and they said that they would not have anything until 7:00pm. At 7:00pm; they had nothing that we wanted; and when I asked them to make me something with no spice; they made it ultra spicy. We then decided to eat the restaurant at Hotel Aishwarya. Food was good thereBut then; as an earlier reviewer said; \At least you have something in Chitradurga.\""

We keep staying in NAveen Hotel; as it is the best available place in Chitradurga. The hotel is located bang on the NH-4 hence; you can't miss it. The management is closely held; so the key person of the hotel is always available to resolve any issues. The staff is not so professionla of star hotels; but; somple boys and happy to help types.There could be some hiccups; but; the boys will fix it. FOr instance; if geyser is not working; don't be surprised. Just cann up the boy and he will come with a bucket of hot water. The restaurant manager is too friendly and courteous. Ever smiling; he will admit his teams mistakes and rectify them to make you happy.Site seeing like fort; temples; Jogi Matti all are close-by. Try Lakshmi Tiffin Centre and Mysore cafe; Chitradurga's oldest places to eat.

the reception is cold. the services are terrible. ordered for food. waited 30 mins. called back n no one made it clear there is no chef. then another half an hour n they tell me they have just 2 options. so by the time i received my order it was 1.5 hrs past and the thing i got was tasteless.service is really poor. keep calling ; n someone might come to help u.will not recommend

I have been expected to live in Hotel Shreenath before the journey started.Even if we have to change our plan due to the cancellation of the train ticket to Jaisalmer;we still decided to get there by bus.The hotel staff picked us up from bus station in the early morning;and cooked breakfast after we checked in.This is a real historic haveli with good location;the temple is quite nearby.Gorgeous room with windows on two walls;wind blows every window if it is opened.The owner Omji treated us like family.He offered us advice on desert safari;restaurant;shopping;and gave us gifts after knowing we were having honeymoon trip.Thanks to Mr.Omji;we left a wonderful memory in Shreenath Place.Hope we can stay here much longer next time:)
Room_Tips: Room Tip: please remember to save water and electric power;because natural resources are difficult to get in d...

Review_Content: We went on a family trip over a weekend. When we reach the Hotel; we were not sure whether to stay or not. But we decided to try the place for the night.....and what a good decision it was. For the first time we felt such love and care from the owners of Shreenath Palace....namely OM Ji; Raj Bhai and Harish. The hospitality was beyond our imagination. Special thanks to wife of OM Ji for the lovely home made food. Overall the experience was very special. I hope to visit them again someday !!
Room_Tips: Room Tip: All rooms are good !!

Review_Title: “Beautiful historic haveli in the heart of the fort”
Review_Content: Our stay in the Hotel Shreenath Palace was without doubt one of the highlights of our visit to Rajasthan. We had booked one of the cheaper rooms but were upgraded to the best room in the hotel on arrival at no extra cost. The Mughai room was filled with stone carved pillars and statues and has an amazing dark wood carved ceiling. The small stone carved balconies look out to the nearby Jain temples which are fascinating to visit. Omji and his two sons were extremely welcoming and helpful of our every need and made us feel part of the family. It was wonderful to stay in the heart of the old fort; we enjoyed it so much we ended up staying 5 nights. Our 13 year old son couldn't believe we were staying in a 450 year old palace. The whole experience was magical. We would highly recommend this unique hotel. David; Anna & Finn Kew; London
Room_Tips: Room Tip: It is worth paying a bit more for one of the bigger rooms which are wonderful.

Review_Content: What a lovely haveli. The rooms are beautiful and the hospitality of everyone is wonderful. Everyone was very caring and looked after us like family. Thank you. We had a great time. We would recommend this place to everyone.Mina and Wendy
Reviewer_Location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
Room_Tips: Room Tip: All the rooms are very tastefully done.

Review_Content: My husband and I stayed two nights in mid-August 2014 at this Haveli and it was a really special experience. Omjee is the most hospitable host we have every come across. I can't even list all of the ways in which he went went the extra mile to make our stay better. We were picked up from the train station; and greeted by name. A welcome sign was waiting for us at the inn; so nice. He arranged for a restaurant to stay open for our late arrival (which we declined; but a very nice gesture). I had a cold from the train ride and he provided me with constant hot lemon water; medications and extra service. They even sent me off with a hot bottle of lemon water; a bone-china cup to drink it out of and a snack bag for the train ride back full of goodies. So incredibly thoughtful. They even let us check-out late; because of our late train; another wonderful perk. We were served a modest breakfast at our leisure each morning and given as much advice about the city as possible. We were upgraded to a nicer room for the second night after just mentioning that there was a little street noise on the first floor (apparently there was a late night festival going on; so it was definitely abnormal). The accommodations are very nice; spectacular rooms; balconies; A/C; great service. They even burned wood to heat up water for our showers; so nice. We will return; and if you visit Jaiselmer; this Haveli is tops; staying here will make your trip so wonderful. It is in the heart of the fort; surrounded by things to see and buy; wonderful.
Room_Tips: Room Tip: All of the rooms seem wonderful; but go for the Maharajah; its spectacular!

Review_Content: I Was looking for an historical haveli with charme And I found even more. The palace And the rooms are beautiful and romantic with colums; decorations; colored curteins And Windows that give an unique atmosphere. Everything remains in the original style no fake modern decoration; you find yourself in the enchant of the ancient india of marajas.
